sources.data_found: The GPU cluster consists of approximately 80 GPU nodes, each equipped with two, four, or eight NVIDIA GPUs.
The ACCRE cluster has approximately 12,000 cores.

The bf[21-24] compute nodes each have four GeForce GTX 1080 GPUs. Compute Nodes bf[1-13,49-51] 20 cores 128GB Memory Broadwell (2.2 GHz), bf[21-24] 8 cores 32GB Memory with GeForce GTX 1080 GPUs (4X).

student_data.notes: Combined undergraduate and graduate enrollment in computer science programs tops 700 students as of 2021. Based on typical university distributions (approximately 80-85% undergrad, 15-20% grad) and the 700 total enrollment: estimated 567 undergrads and 133 graduate students. PhD counts could not be separated from MS counts in available sources. DataUSA shows 282 total CS degrees awarded in 2023 (205 to men, 77 to women), which aligns with the enrollment estimates. [WARNING: Original source was inaccessible, using fallback.]

other_high_vram_gpus.notes: 48 nodes × 4 GPUs per node = 192 GPUs (VUIIS cluster)
4 nodes × 4 GPUs per node = 16 GPUs (Bluefin CSB cluster bf[21-24])

gpu_resources.notes: ACCRE GPU cluster consists of approximately 80 GPU nodes with 2, 4, or 8 GPUs each. Exact GPU models and counts for the main ACCRE cluster were not specified in available sources. The VUIIS cluster has 48 nodes with 4× GTX 480 GPUs each (192 total), and the Bluefin CSB cluster has 4 nodes with 4× GTX 1080 GPUs each (16 total). No evidence of H100, A100, or other modern datacenter GPUs was found in the search results.

analysis_notes: Data collected from ACCRE (Advanced Computing Center for Research & Education) technical documentation and departmental enrollment information. GPU resources appear to be older generation consumer/workstation GPUs rather than modern datacenter GPUs. The 2021 enrollment figure of 700+ CS students is the most recent concrete data found.
